Topic: Draw reversible and irreversible changes (ice melting vs. egg cooking)
Evidence Statements: The student can draw the starting materials before heating or cooling, like ice before melting or a raw egg before cooking.
The student can illustrate what happens to the material after heating, such as ice turning to water or a raw egg solidifying.
The student can show what happens to the material after cooling, like water freezing back into ice or how a cooked egg stays solid.
The student can depict whether the changes are reversible, such as ice melting and refreezing, or irreversible, like a cooked egg staying solid.
The student can label drawings to demonstrate understanding of cause and effect, showing how heating or cooling leads to observable changes.
